g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
their respective conversion and cultivation emission factors. ‘IAM
EMF33’ refers to emissions factors for advanced biofuels derived from simulation results from the
integrated assessment models EMF33 scenarios. ‘PM’ refers to partial models, where ‘CLC’ is
constant land cover and ‘NRG’ is with natural regrowth. ‘Hydrogen, low
carbon electricity. ‘Hydrogen, natural gas SMR’ refers to fuels produced via
steam methane reforming of natural gas.
The tailpipe emissions and fuel consumption reported in the literature generally do not use empirical
emissions data. Rather, they tend to report fuel efficiency using driving cycles such as New European
Driving Cycle (NEDC) or the US EPA Federal Test Proc
edure. As a result, depending on the driving
cycle used, operating emissions reported in literature are possibly underestimated by as much as 15
38%, in comparison to actual real driving emissions
. The extent of these underestimations, however, vary between
Current average life cycle impacts of mid
size ICEVs span from approximately 65 g CO
, with both values stemming from ICEVs running on biofuels. Between this range
life cycle impacts of 130 g CO
consumption dominates the life cycle emissions of ICEVs, with approximately 75% of
arising from the tailpipe and fuel chain.
(PHEVs) vary in terms of degree of powertrain electrification. HEVs mainly
rely on regenerative braking for charging the battery. PHEVs combine regenerative braking with
external power sources for charging the battery. Operating emissions intensity is hig
the degree to which electrified driving is performed, which in turn is user
PHEVs, emissions intensity is also dependent on the source of the electricity for charging. HEV and
e to the emissions generated for producing ICEVs as the
batteries are generally small compared to those of BEVs
compared to ICEVs by up to 30%, depending on the fuel, yielding median life cycle intensities varying
NRG). Within this wide range, all the combinations of electric/fossil driving can be found, as well as
the life cycle intensity for driving 100% on fossil fuel. Bec
ause HEVs rely on combustion as the main
energy conversion process, they offer limited mitigation opportunities. However, HEVs represent a
suitable temporary solution, yielding a moderate mitigation potential, in areas where the electricity mix
y so carbon intensive that the use of PHEVs and BEVs is not an effective mitigation solution
In contrast to HEVs, PHEVs may provide greater opportunities for us
LDVs. These increased potential benefits are due to the ability to charge the battery with low
electric range in comparison to HEVs
behaviour (e.g., utility factor (UF) and charging patterns), manufacturer settings, and access to
renewable electricity for charging strongly influence the total operational impacts
UF is a weighting of the percentage of distance covered using the electric charge (charge depleting (CD)
stage) versus the distance covered using the internal combustion engine (charge sustaining
. When the PHEV operates in C
S mode, the internal combustion engine is used for
propulsion and to maintain the state of charge of the battery within a certain range, together with
. When running in CS mode, PHEVs
potential and have impacts comparable to those of HEVs. On the other hand,
when the PHEV operates in CD mode, the battery alone provides the required propulsion energy
. Thus, in CD mode, PHEVs hold potential for higher mitigatio
